So you don't ever have any bug in production code? Wow!

Well, I don't have as much confidence in my code, so I would want to handle
possible assertion-exceptions.

ciao, Ilja

-----Ursprungliche Nachricht-----
Von: Alan Francis [mailto:alan@...]
Gesendet: Donnerstag, 25. Januar 2001 14:24
An: junit@egroups.com
Betreff: [junit] Re: Programming By Contract


--- In junit@egroups.com, tony.heap@t... wrote:
>
> What about in a production system where I don't want a poor end
> user to be troubled with 20 or so lines of exception stack trace,
> and more importantly, I want to ask them very nicely to report the
> error to  tech support.

Doctor, doctor, it hurts when I use assertions to handle possible
exception situations.

(all together now...) don't do that.

You shouldn't have failing assertions in production code.  They'll
have failed during testing and you'll have fixed it.  What you want
in production code is a decent error-handling strategy (which IMO PbC
is not).

Asserts for preconditions (and junit UTs for postconditions) are
a "testing strategy", not an "error-handiling strategy".


Alan

subject: AW: [junit] Re: Programming By Contract
